title:
The Efficacy and Safety of DLBS3233, A Combined Bioactive
Fraction of
abstract:
A bioactive fraction of  This was a 2-arm, randomized, double-blind, controlled, noninferiority clinical study over
a 6-month therapy with DLBS3233 100-mg daily in comparison to metformin-XR 750 mg twice daily, involving 124
PCOS women with insulin resistance. The primary efficacy endpoint was the improvement of Homeostasis Model
Assessment-Insulin Resistance (HOMA-IR). Secondary endpoints were improvements in other metabolic and reproductive
parameters. Safety endpoints were based on blood pressure, heart rate, electrocardiogram findings, liver and
renal function, and adverse events. After 6 months, HOMA-IR improvement in DLBS3233-treated group (-1.03 ± 0.50) and metformin-XR (-1.19
± 0.50) were comparable, with a between-group difference fell within the pre-set non-inferiority margin (0.16; 95% confidence
interval (CI): -1.24, 1.56; P=0.3168). The HOMA-IR in both groups were significantly improved from baseline.
On all secondary endpoints, both groups showed comparable effects. Markedly fewer adverse events occurred in the
DLBS3233 treated group than in the Metformin-XR-treated group and most were mild clinically and had been resolved
by the end of the study. Treatment with DLBS3233 100-mg daily in PCOS women demonstrated comparable efficacy to metformin-
XR 750-mg twice daily in improving insulin resistance. However, the non-inferiority of DLBS3233 to metformin-
XR remains inconclusive. DLBS3233 was more tolerable than metformin-XR (registration number: NCT01733459).
body:
Introduction  Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine condition affecting women of reproductive age, with a prevalence between 8 and 13% ( 1 ). The
clinical characteristics of PCOS are hyperandrogenism,
ovarian dysfunction indicated by menstrual irregularity,
and polycystic morphology of the ovary ( 2 ). PCOS has a
complex multifactorial etiology, sharing highly polygenic
and environmental influences ( 2 , 3 ). Insulin resistance,
with its compensatory hyperinsulinemia, is regarded as one key risk factor of the PCOS pathogenesis which further enhances the hyperandrogenism condition ( 4 , 5 ).
Insulin resistance affects approximately 70% of PCOS
women ( 4 ). Obesity and abdominal adiposity, other common findings in PCOS patients, also suggest a strong link
between insulin resistance and PCOS ( 2 ). Clinical evidence also showed that improvement of insulin sensitivity
provides various beneficial effects in these patients ( 4 , 6 ).  Currently, treatment for PCOS is symptomatic, and the
search for a single treatment that addresses both reproductive and metabolic abnormalities is still underway. Oral
contraceptive pills (OCPs) are the first-line pharmacological management for menstrual irregularity and hyperandrogenism ( 1 , 7 ); while clomiphene, aromatase inhibitors (such as letrozole), or gonadotropins, which involve
ovulation induction, are therapies that address infertility
( 2 , 8 ). Those mainstream therapies alone will be insufficient for PCOS patients to recover their metabolic and
reproductive health since it does not interfere with insulin
resistance. Insulin sensitizing agents should be given in
conjunction with lifestyle management, weight reduction
and exercise, which serve as the primary therapy for insulin resistance and its consequent metabolic features in
PCOS ( 6 ). The currently recommended insulin-sensitizing drug is metformin, which is commonly used in combination with OCPs and anti-androgen medications to target
hyperandrogenemia and its symptoms, restore menstrual
regularity, aid in weight reduction, and improve metabolic parameters, with the ultimate goal of preventing
long-term metabolic and cardiovascular complications
( 6 , 9 ). Despite promising clinical responses, metformin
has been associated with several unexpected side effects
( 10 ). There is a significant need for continual research to
deliver more options of mechanism-based directed interventions for this condition.  DLBS3233, a specific bioactive fraction of two native Indonesian plants, Cinnamomum
burmanii and Lagerstroemia speciosa , possesses an
insulin-sensitizing property. It pharmacologically demonstrated the ability to enhance the
insulin-signal transduction ( 11 , 12 ). Toxicity studies have proven the safety of DLBS3233
( 13 , 14 ). A previous study on healthy volunteers also reported the tolerability and safety
of DLBS3233 ( 15 ). A 12-week study in subjects with impaired glucose tolerance demonstrated
clinical benefits of DLBS3233 in improving insulin resistance, which were indicated by a
significant reduction of Homeostasis Model Assessment-Insulin Resistance (HOMAIR), and
preservation of β -cell performance ( 16 ). Another clinical study reported
several clinical benefits of 100 mg once daily of DLBS3233 in type-2-diabetes subjects who
were inadequately controlled by metformin and other oral anti-diabetic agents, in enhancing
glycemic control, insulin sensitivity, lipid profile, and elevating the adiponectin level.
Concomitant DLBS3233 treatment with other oral anti-diabetic agents was also proven safe and
tolerable in type-2-diabetes subjects ( 17 ).    Materials and Methods   Subjects and study design  This was a 2-arm, randomized, controlled, doubleblind, and non-inferiority study over a six-month treatment period with DLBS3233 in 124 women with PCOS.
This study was set at the Yasmin Fertility Clinic Kencana, Dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo, Jakarta, Indonesia, and
Aster Fertility Clinic, Hasan Sadikin Hospital, Bandung,
West Java, Indonesia, and conducted in compliance with
the Declaration of Helsinki, Good Clinical Practice, and
relevant local regulatory requirements. The Independent
Ethics Committee of Universitas Indonesia, Jakarta, Indonesia, reviewed and approved the study protocol with
the Ethical Clearance (605/H2.F1/ETIK/2012). The protocol was registered with a clinical trial registry number
of NCT01733459.  Each subject provided a written informed consent, prior to screening. The followings were
the eligibility criteria for the study: i. Reproductive-aged (18-40 years old) female, ii.
Diagnosis of PCOS confirmed by the presence of two or more of Rotterdam criteria ( 1 ):
hyperandrogenism (defined as the elevation of free testosterone concentration or
Ferriman-Gallwey score (FGS) of ≥ 8, ( 18 ), oligomenorrhea (or amenorrhea) after a negative
screening pregnancy test, and the presence of polycystic ovary morphology on
ultrasonography (USG); iii. Insulin resistance, defined by HOMA-IR >2.00 ( 19 ). Exclusion
criteria were pregnancy or lactation; hyperandrogenism that was associated with Cushing’s
syndrome, late onset of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, androgen-secreting tumours,
uncontrolled thyroid disease, or hyperprolactinemia; having a medical condition that could
interfere with the study evaluation, such as: diabetes mellitus, defined as a fasting
plasma glucose (FPG) level ≥7.0 mmol/L or a 2-hour postprandial glucose (2h-PG) ≥11.1
mmoL/L at a 75 g oral glucose challenge test; uncontrolled hypertension, defined as a
systolic blood pressure (SBP) and/or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) >160/100 mmHg; other
cardiovascular diseases, such as symptomatic ischaemic heart disease, unstable angina,
heart failure; acute or chronic infections, any known malignancies; an impaired renal
function, defined as a serum creatinine level >1.5-fold upper limit of normal (ULN); an
impaired liver function, defined as a serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level ≥2.5-fold
ULN; being under a medically-assisted weightloss therapy, laparoscopic ovarian diathermy
(LOD), or in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment; regularly taking any
medications affecting insulin sensitivity as well as reproductive function within the past
three months, such as clomiphene citrate, insulin sensitizers (such as metformin and
thiazolidindiones), aromatase inhibitors (such as anastrozole and letrozole),
glucocorticoids, gonadotropins, gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (GnRHa), OCPs,
antiandrogens [such as spironolactone, cyproterone acetate (CPA), and flutamide], or any
herbal medicines; or participating in another clinical trial within 30 days prior to
screening.  Subjects would be withdrawn from the study due to
safety concerns, such as hypersensitivity, or clinically
unacceptable hypoglycaemia (FPG or random plasma
glucose (RPG) <3.9 mmol/L), or if they took a systemic
treatment with glucocorticoids for more than one week
during the present study participation.  The randomization was prepared by using the permuted
four-block-allocation and table of random numbers. Subject recruitment was carried out according to the consecutive sampling method. Randomization and blinding codes
were prepared by the study sponsor independent unit.  The efficacy metabolic parameters were evaluated at
baseline and every 3-month interval over the 6-month
study period, while the efficacy reproductive parameters,
as well as safety parameters, were evaluated at the Baseline and End of the study. Since the study was neither designed to evaluate the effect of a lifestyle intervention nor
the study treatment on top of it, general counselling on
lifestyle modification was provided by the assigned investigators at baseline and every follow-up visit, but it
was not strictly controlled during subjects’ participation
in our present study.  The primary efficacy endpoint was the improvement
(reduction) in the insulin resistance that was indicated by
the HOMA-IR after 6 months of treatment. The secondary efficacy endpoints were the improvements in other
metabolic and reproductive outcomes. The former included the glucose tolerance improvement that was indicated
by the serum levels of FPG, 2h-PG, and fasting insulin,
and in the lipid profile (low-density lipoprotein [LDL],
high-density lipoprotein [HDL], triglycerides, total cholesterol). The latter included FGS, serum free androgen
index (FAI), luteinizing hormone (LH) level, LH/follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) ratio, the ratio between
stroma and total area of median ovarian section (S/A ratio), menstrual cycle normalization, ovulation rate, and
pregnancy rate. The following technical methods were
used to measure the above mentioned parameters: Glucose hexokinase (glucose) Immunochemiluminescence
(fasting insulin), Cholesterol Oxidase–Aminoantypirin Peroxidase [CHOD/PAP] (cholesterol), colorimetric
Gliserolphosphate Oxidase-Aminoantipyrine Peroxidase
[GPO/PAP] (triglyceride), chemiluminescent microparticle immunoassay [CMIA] (LH, FSH), electrochemiluminescence immunoassay [ECLIA] (testosterone).  Safety endpoints were at the end of study values of vital
signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate,
electrocardiography (ECG), liver function parameters, including serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST), serum
ALT, alkaline phosphatase (AP), γ-glutamyl transferase
(GGT), renal function parameters, including serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN). Any adverse events
(AEs) were monitored and carefully evaluated along the
study course.    Study treatment  The investigational product, DLBS3233 bioactive fraction (InlacinTM capsules, PT Dexa
Medica, Indonesia), is a nature-derived product of the Indonesian native plants, including Cinnamomum burmanii and Lagerstroemia speciosa . The
extraction procedure and the phytochemical characterization of DLBS3233 were detailed
elsewhere ( 12 , 15 ). Each formulated capsule of the investigational product contains 100 mg
of DLBS3233.  Eligible subjects were randomized in a blinded fashion, to receive either DLBS3233 100 mg once daily
(investigational group) or metformin extended release
(XR) caplets (PT Dexa Medica, Indonesia) 750 mg twice
daily (control group), for six months. The placebos of
DLBS3233 and metformin, which were provided by PT
Dexa Medica, Indonesia, were administered at the same
regimen as that of their corresponding active drugs. Each
study subject received either DLBS3233 capsule and placebo metformin-XR placebo; or metformin-XR caplet and
DLBS3233 placebo. The placebos were basically dummies of DLBS3233 capsules and metformin-XR caplets
without the active substances. Furthermore, the monitors
and data analysts were also blind to the allocation during
our present study conduct.  During participating in the study, subjects were not allowed to take systemic treatment with any of the listed
medicines: Clomiphene citrate, insulin sensitizers (e.g.
metformin and thiazolidindiones), aromatase inhibitors
(e.g. anastrozole and letrozole), gonadotropins, GnRHa,
OCP, antiandrogens (e.g. spironolactone, CPA, flutamide), any herbal medicines affecting the insulin sensitivity and reproductive functions. Any other concomitant
medication taken by study subjects or its modifications
during their participation in the study was recorded and
evaluated.    Statistical analysis  The hypothesis of interest for the primary efficacy
endpoint was that after 6 months of treatment, the reduction of HOMA-IR in subjects receiving DLBS3233
was not inferior to that of metformin, with the noninferiority margin was set at δ=0.5 points, following
the protocol. Sample size calculation was based on the
primary efficacy endpoint. Using the type I error rate
(α) of 0.05, a statistical power of 0.85 and the non-inferiority margin of HOMA-IR reduction between groups
of 0.5 points, with a standard deviation of 0.9, ( 20 ) a
total of 96 subjects (48 subjects in each group) was
required to complete the study. A total of 124 subjects (62 subjects in each group) were enrolled to anticipate
a withdrawal rate of 20%.  A full analysis set, defined as the set of subjects that is
as close as possible to the ideal intent-to-treat (ITT) principle, was analysed for the efficacy evaluation. It consisted of all subjects who were randomized, took at least one
dose of the study product, and generated at least one data
of the primary efficacy endpoint after treatment initiation.
The safety data set included those who received at least
one dose of the study product.  A repeated-measures model was applied for the analysis of the primary efficacy endpoint and other continuous
outcomes which had more than one time-point of measurement. Other efficacy and safety continuous variables
were compared between groups by independent t-test, assuming normality of data distribution and equality of the
variances. The corresponding non-parametric test would
be used when the assumptions were not met. All statistical analysis was performed at a significance level of 0.05.
Categorical outcomes (ovulation rate, pregnancy rate, and
the normalization of menstrual cycle) were analysed using the Chi-square test. The data analysis was generated
using IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows (Version 20.0.
Armonk, NY: IBM Corp).     Results   Participants and baseline characteristics  Between March 18, 2013 and August 24, 2017, a total of 124 patients were enrolled in the present study. Of
them, 106 subjects were eligible for the ITT analysis; and
the remaining 18 subjects consisted of one screening failure and 17 subjects with no available post-treatment data.
There were 14 subjects who ended the study earlier due
to pregnancy. Figure 1 displays the subject disposition in
the study, with only two subjects, one in each group, withdrawn due to adverse events.  Demographic and baseline characteristics, as well as
medical history and concomitant medication, are summarized in Table 1. The prevalences of several characteristics of metabolic syndrome (MetS) in both groups (Table
S1, See Supplementary Online Information at www.ijfs.
ir) were not statistically different between groups, with
low HDL (HDL below 1.30 mmol/L, observed in 71.2 vs.
61.1% of subjects in DLBS322 and metformin-XR group,
respectively) and followed by the central obesity (waist
circumference ≥ 88 cm, observed in 76.9 vs. 77.8% of
subjects, respectively) prevailed. No concomitant medications in both groups might significantly interfere with
the study treatment evaluation.   Fig 1   Subject disposition. One subject might experience more than one medical
history. One subject might use more than one concomitant medication during the
study. All baseline characteristics were comparable between groups (P>0.05). a ; Percentages are based on the total number of subjects in the
corresponding group, 2h-PG; 2-hour postprandial glucose, ALT; Alanine
aminotransferase, AMH; Anti-Mϋllerian hormone, AP; Alkaline phosphatase, AST;
Aspartate aminotransferase, BMI; Body mass index, BUN; Blood urea nitrogen, CM;
Concomitant medication, DBP; Diastolic blood pressure, FI; Fasting insulin, FPG;
Fasting plasma glucose, FSH; Follicle stimulating hormone, HDL; High-density
lipoprotein, HOMA-IR; Homeostasis model assessment-insulin resistance, LDL;
Low-density lipoprotein, LH; Luteinizing hormone, SBP; Systolic blood pressure, and
TSH; Thyroid stimulating hormone.       Primary efficacy endpoint (improved insulin sensitivity)  Table 2 and Figure 2 indicate that there was no statistically significant difference between DLBS3233 and Metformin XR Group, in HOMA-IR reduction from baseline,
at some evaluation time-point; yet, the non-inferiority of
DLBS3233 to metformin-XR was inconclusive. In addition, the HOMA-IR values at each time point were also
analysed within-each group as displayed in Table 3 and
Figure 2. At any time-point, HOMA-IR values between
groups were not statistically different. Meanwhile, a significant reduction in the HOMA-IR value after three and
six months of treatment was found in DLBS3233 as well
as Metformin XR Group. Nevertheless, the improvement
profiles in both groups slightly differed. With metforminXR treatment, the HOMA-IR improvement was prominent
after 3 months but gradually attenuated from 3 to 6 months.
In contrast, the HOMA-IR improvement with DLBS3233
treatment was consistently increasing over time. Each variable refers to the improvement of the corresponding value at each time
point to the value at baseline, b ; Difference; mean improvement of each
variable in DLBS3233 group subtracted by mean improvement in Metformin XR group, c ; P value of the difference, unless otherwise mentioned, d ; P value from 1-tailed test for non-inferiority, 2h-PG; 2-hour
postprandial glucose, ALT; Alanine aminotransferase, AMH; Anti-Mϋllerian hormone,
AP; Alkaline phosphatase, AST; Aspartate aminotransferase, BMI; Body mass index,
BUN; Blood urea nitrogen, CM; Concomitant medication, DBP; Diastolic blood pressure,
FAI; Free androgen index, FI; Fasting insulin, FPG; Fasting plasma glucose, FSH;
Follicle stimulating hormone, HDL; High-density lipoprotein, HOMA-IR; Homeostasis
model assessment-insulin resistance, LDL; Low density lipoprotein, LH; Luteinizing
hormone, SBP; Systolic blood pressure, FGS; Ferriman gallway score, and TSH; Thyroid
stimulating hormone.       Secondary efficacy endpoints  Table 2 illustrates the comparative analysis of all continuous secondary efficacy endpoints. The outcomes
referred to the improvement or changes of each parameter from baseline were evaluated at each time-point,
and compared between groups. In addition, the absolute
values of each parameter at each time point were also
compared between groups as well as within groups, as
presented in Table 3.  Table 2 shows that there was no significant betweengroup difference in all secondary metabolic (i.e. the
improvement of FPG, 2h-PG, fasting insulin, lipid
profile) and reproductive endpoints (i.e. the improvement of FGS, FAI, LH level, LH/FSH ratio, (S/A) ratio), after 3 and 6 months of treatment. Neither was a
significant between-group difference observed in the
absolute values of those variables at each time point
( Table 3 ).  However, within-group analyses in Table 3 demonstrated significant metabolic improvements
to either DLBS3233 or metformin-XR treatment. Fasting insulin in both groups at Months
3 rd and 6 th was significantly lower from their respective
baseline. The LDL level was reduced gradually during 3 and 6 months of treatment with
DLBS3233. The reduction was greater in the Metformin XR Group than the DLBS3233 after 3
months of treatment; but after 6 months, the LDL level in the Metformin XR Group returned
to a similar value with the baseline. The profile of LDL changes in each group was similar
to that of the HOMA-IR. Further, the improvement of total cholesterol levels in both
groups was perfectly aligned with the LDLcholesterol level. Consequently, the profile of
total cholesterol level at each time point within each group was similar to the
LDL-cholesterol level. On the other hand, HDL levels were not altered at each time point
after administration of either DLBS3233 or metformin-XR. In both groups, the triglyceride
level was reduced significantly at the 3 rd month and remained stable up to the
6 th month.   Fig 2   Homeostasis Model Assessment-Insulin Resistance (HOMA-IR)
profiles. The differences between groups and within groups were ana- lysed using the independent t test and repeated-measures, respec- tively.     In terms of reproductive improvements, within-group analyses revealed that the right S/A
ratio at the 6 th month was significantly lower than the baseline value with
DLBS3233 treatment, but it was not the case with Metformin-XR. Both BMI and waist
circumference were reduced over time in both treatment groups. A decreasing trend of body
fat was observed in the Metformin-XR group, but it slightly fluctuated in the DLBS3233
group. The FAI was lowered significantly from baseline in the DLBS3233 group, but not in
the Metformin-XR.  We did not observe a significant different rate of
pregnancy and also ovulation rate between groups
(Table S2, See Supplementary Online Information at
www.ijfs.ir). In addition, the ovulation rate seemed
not to improve over the study period in both groups.
It seems that Metformin-XR treatment may reduce the
median cycle length between the last two menstrual
(Table S3, See Supplementary Online Information at
www.ijfs.ir).    Safety to organ functions  All laboratory safety parameters showed clinically normal values at each time point, indicating that
both treatments did not adversely affect all laboratory
safety parameters. Besides, no significant differences
between groups in all safety parameters, with the exception of serum creatinine, were observed at the end
of the study ( Table 4 ). We observed a slightly different serum Creatinine value between groups, although
they were still within the normal range. Further, ECG
examination of all subjects in both groups at the baseline and end of the study showed normal or variant
normal results.    Adverse events  Most adverse events were considered mild and not
related to the investigational drug. Adverse events
considered related to the study treatment (either
DLBS3233 or Metformin XR) were as the following:
dizziness, vertigo, appetite exaggerated, nausea, generalized weakness, headache, diarrhoea, diaphoresis,
shaking, vomiting, abdominal pain, and palpitation.
Overall, there was a two-fold lower rate of drug-related adverse events with DLBS3233 treatment than
that of Metformin XR treatment, particularly those
categorized as gastrointestinal disturbances (Table S4,
See Supplementary Online Information at www.ijfs.
ir), such as diarrhoea (21.0 vs. 45.2%), nausea (11.3
vs. 19.4%), vomiting (3.2 vs. 11.3%), and dyspepsia
(1.6 vs. 17.8%), (DLBS3233 and metformin-XR treatment groups, respectively). A total of 150 adverse
events were experienced by 37 (59.7%) subjects in the
DLBS3233 group, compared to a total of 253 events,
which 50 (80.6%) subjects experienced in the Metformin XR Group during the study. There was no serious adverse event (SAE) encountered during the study.
No adverse events remained unresolved by the end of
the study.  One subject in each group was withdrawn from the
study due to an adverse event. The adverse events were
moderately severe ovarian cyst, in the DLBS3233 Group,
which was more relevant to disease progression, and severe nausea, in the Metformin Group, which was considered related to drug use. SBP; Systolic blood
pressure, DBP; Diastolic blood pressure, AST; Aspartate aminotransferase, ALT; Alanine
aminotransferase, GT; Glutamyl transferase, AP; Alkaline phosphatase, and BUN; Blood
urea nitrogen.        Discussion  In the present study, we found a significant amelioration of insulin resistance after three
and six months of treatment with DLBS3233 as well as Metformin-XR. Although, the trends of
the HOMA-IR reduction were considerably different among groups, with MetforminXR Group
showed a more prominent improvement during the early 3 months, while it was attenuated
afterward; and also a more stable improvement was seen with the DLBS3233 treatment over the
6-month period. At Month 6 th , the improvement of insulin resistance with DLBS3233
was comparable to that of metformin-XR, with the point estimate of between-group difference
within the non-inferiority margin. Yet, the non-inferiority of DLBS3233 to metformin-XR
remained statistically inconclusive.  It is widely perceived that PCOS is associated with the peripheral insulin resistance and
hyperinsulinemia ( 2 , 4 - 6 ). Currently, there is neither the best surrogate index for insulin
resistance, nor a universal ‘cut-off’ point to define insulin resistance in a clinical
practice for PCOS women. However, the HOMA-IR model has proved to be a robust clinical and
epidemiological tool for the assessment of insulin resistance, since it has a significant
correlation with the insulin resistance measured by the standard hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic
clamp ( 21 ). The HOMA-IR cut-off point of 2.00 used in this study was determined based on
data from our clinical practice; that was approximately close to those commonly used in PCOS
women of Asian populations ( 19 ). The DLBS3233 efficacy on the improvement of insulin
resistance was aligned with that previously demonstrated in prediabetes ( 16 ), conforming to
its known mechanism of action ( 11 , 12 ). DLBS3233 treatment modulates the expression levels
of different genes, including Phosphatidylinositol (PI)-3-kinase, peroxisome
proliferators-activator receptor (PPAR)-γ and PPAR-δ , while all
of them are involved in the insulin-signalling transduction that regulates insulin
sensitivity. The PPAR-γ and PPAR-δ gene activation by
DLBS3233 treatment explains its promising metabolic effects on the glucose and lipid
profiles in insulin resistance-associated diseases, such as type-2-diabetes ( 17 , 22 ), as
well as PCOS.  In this study, PCOS subjects who had diabetes mellitus
as co-morbidity were excluded. Therefore, a significant
reduction in both FPG and 2h-PG would not be expected
either. Further, no hypoglycemic event was observed with
DLBS3233 or metformin-XR treatment, suggesting that
both medications do not reduce the serum glucose level in
normo-glycemic subjects. Specifically with DLBS3233
treatment, such a characteristic was aligned with the
finding of our previous study in healthy volunteers, which
reported a negligible risk of DLBS3233 to induce hypoglycemia ( 15 ).  Since the fasting glucose level was not affected by
DLBS3233 treatment, the reduction of HOMA-IR value
by the drug was strongly correlated with the reduction of
fasting insulin level. Our finding of the DLBS3233 capacity to ameliorate fasting insulin level as previously reported by Manaf et al. ( 16 ) in prediabetic patients. On the
other hand, even though studies of metformin demonstrated discordance in terms of whether the insulin resistance
amelioration by the drug resulted from its effect on fasting insulin ( 23 , 24 ), our study positively suggested it did.  Further, insulin resistance is a central player in metabolic syndrome (MetS). Insulin resistance is highly prevalent
in PCOS women; therefore most PCOS women are also
considered susceptible to MetS ( 6 ). Of several metabolic
abnormalities characterizing MetS, we found that lower
HDL level (<1.30 mmol/L) and central obesity (waist circumference ≥ 88 cm) predominated and were comparable
in both groups. The predominant low HDL-cholesterol
best explains the high prevalence of MetS in PCOS subjects in whom insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia
play key roles ( 25 ). Similarly, a low HDL concentration
was also prevailing in our study. Similar to previous studies ( 23 , 24 , 26 ), we found no evidence of metformin’s effect on the serum HDL cholesterol level. This study also
demonstrated a neutral effect of the DLBS3233 on the
HDL concentration, which in fact, corresponds to a similar finding in our previous study with DLBS3233 treatment in type-2 diabetes mellitus ( 17 ).  Despite the inefficacy on the HDL concentration, both metformin and DLBS3233 appeared to
interfere with other lipid components, such as LDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides.
Metformin had been demonstrated to be beneficial in ameliorating dyslipidemia ( 27 ). In our
study, however, while the reduction of LDL and total cholesterol with metformin treatment
was significant at Month 3 rd , the values gradually returned to the points close
to their respective baseline at Month 6 th . Such a pattern was consistent with
that seen on the HOMA-IR attenuation by DLBS3233. In contrast, the LDL and total cholesterol
alleviation were more stable over a treatment period with DLBS3233, resulting in a
significant improvement at Month 6 th . As for triglycerides, the patterns in both
groups were similar, in which the improvement was continued from 3 to 6 months of treatment.
Further, given that the mean values of the lipid profile were actually within the normal
ranges at the Baseline, it is not surprising that there was only a little room for the
variables to improve, in which we observed no significant difference between groups either.
Such within-group significant improvement and between-group comparability altogether
indicated that DLBS3233 showed favourable effects on lipid profile, with a more favourable
improvement-pattern than that of metformin. The benefit of DLBS3233 on the lipid profile
demonstrated in this study is consistent with similar findings in our previous studies ( 12 , 16 , 17 , 22 ).  The other characteristic PCOS features, such as a higher BMI and an elevated waist circumference were also
comparable between groups at baseline. Based on the
WHO classification on BMI and the Indonesian BMI
cut-off value ( 28 ), our study population was considered
as overweight and obese, respectively, at baseline. Both
DLBS3233 and metformin treatments resulted in a modest, yet statistically significant, BMI reduction over 6
months of the treatment period. This finding was in contrast to our previous DLBS3233 studies in prediabetes
( 16 ), and type-2-diabetes ( 17 ), which reported insignificant changes in BMI. It seems that the baseline BMI interferes with the extent to which DLBS3233 can reduce
BMI; where with higher BMI, such as overweight and
obese, DLBS3233 that acts as an insulin sensitizing agent
may work better. Similarly, there was not an agreement
among studies about the effect of Metformin treatment on
BMI in PCOS women. Whilst most studies proved that
metformin treatment benefited PCOS subjects in reducing BMI ( 1 , 2 , 7 , 24 , 26 ), some studies reported its neutral
effect on BMI or body weight ( 23 ). Issues such as the
characteristic diversity of the study population, dose of
metformin, concomitant lifestyle implemented, and subject adherence to treatment might explain the variation in
findings among studies.  We found that the profile of waist circumference at each
time point within each group was perfectly aligned with
that of BMI. The intra-abdominal or visceral fat distribution is crucial in developing insulin resistance. In our
study, body fat reduction was observed along the treatment period with metformin, which was in agreement
with former studies ( 29 - 31 ). Meanwhile, consistent with
its effect on BMI, DLBS3233 also seemed to favourably
influence body fat, though only after 6 months of treatment. Further, the reduction of body fat with DLBS3233
was also comparable to that observed with metformin.
This result suggests the potential of DLBS323 for weight
management in PCOS.  Since there is a strong relationship between insulin
resistance and hyperandrogenism in PCOS ( 4 , 5 ), amelioration of insulin resistance would consequently favor
PCOS women in attenuating clinical signs of androgen
overproduction. This was also the case with our study
findings. DLBS3233 significantly attenuated the FAI after a 6-month of treatment. However, differing from the
established benefit of metformin to attenuate hyperandrogenism in PCOS ( 1 - 3 , 6 , 10 ), our study failed to show the
efficacy of metformin in reducing FAI. Whether or not
the non-obese characteristic of our study subjects at baseline accounted for our negative finding with metformin,
should still be further investigated. A former study by
Onalan et al. ( 32 ) reported that it was the subgroup of
hyperinsulinaemic obese PCOS women who would benefit from metformin therapy. Diverse hormonal profiles
among PCOS women as well as various assessment methods applied might contribute to the different results between studies.  Hirsutism, a bothersome manifestation due to androgen overproduction in PCOS ( 33 ), develops gradually
and intensifies with weight gain ( 9 ). Hirsutism is usually
graded using the Ferriman-Gallwey Scale (FGS) ( 3 ) with
the recommended cut-off value of ≥8 in most populations,
for hyperandrogenism diagnosis. Our study population in
both groups showed a baseline FGS score above 5, which
was actually sufficient to suspect hyperandrogenic disorder. Azziz ( 3 ) reported that an FGS score ≥ 3 defines abnormal terminal body or facial hair growth that should be
examined for hyperandrogenic disorder. Indeed, hyperandrogenemia in our study was confirmed by the elevated
FAI at baseline. The FAI is considered among the best
biochemical markers for the diagnosis of hyperandrogenism ( 8 ). Further, the degree of hirsutism is an indicator of
metabolic dysfunction severity ( 3 ). We simply observed
that aligned with the modest baseline FGS scores, our
study subjects were regarded to have only mild to moderate metabolic dysfunction, which was reflected by normal or nearly normal baseline values of glucose level,
lipid profile, and waist circumference. The insignificant
changes of FGS score observed in our study suggested
that neither Metformin nor DLBS3233 had a considerable effect on hirsutism. This may partly be attributed to
the modest FGS score at Baseline. The association was
confirmed by other Metformin studies which also found
a minor improvement of hirsutism at a smaller baseline
FGS score ( 24 , 30 ), in contrast with another study demonstrating a significant improvement in greater baseline
FGS score ( 31 ). In addition, the interpretation using this
scale should be done with caution because of its subjective nature.  Despite evident hyperandrogenism in our study subjects, their basal LH concentration and LH/FSH ratio
at baseline in both groups were comparably within the
normal ranges. Thus, it is not surprising that both variables were unaffected by either Metformin or DLBS3233
treatment. Normal LH/FSH ratios in PCOS patients are
not uncommon. Malini and Roy George ( 34 ) observed
that PCOS has different ranges of the LH/FSH ratio of
<1 range to 4.6-5.5, which means including the normal
range. Moreover, even though a ratio greater than 2 generally indicates PCOS, there are no exact cut-off values
since many different assays are used ( 33 ).  Insulin resistance disrupts the hypothalamic-pituitaryovarian axis, leading to increased LH production, which
in turn implicating in ovulatory dysfunction and amenorrhea ( 6 ). Metformin alone in women with PCOS improved the menstrual cycle, ovulation and clinical pregnancy rates, with the best outcome when it is combined
with clomiphene ( 3 , 6 , 10 , 23 ). Despite the amelioration
of insulin resistance found in this study, both metformin
and DLBS3233 did not significantly affect clinical reproductive parameters, such as ovulation and pregnancy
rates. Yet, the rates of regular menstrual cycle tended to
increase after taking either treatment for 6 months, with
a significantly shorter cycle-length with metformin-XR
treatment. In addition, there was a considerable reduction of the S/A ratio on ultrasonography after 6 months
of treatment with DLBS3233, indicating PCOS amelioration. Nevertheless, the effect was regarded modest
since the S/A ratios after treatment were still beyond the
cut-off of >0.34, which was identified as a reliable and
reproducible diagnostic marker for PCOS. However, the
improvement of insulin resistance in PCOS subjects of
the 6-month treatment of DLBS3233 was not necessarily
followed by the improvement in reproductive outcomes,
such as menstrual regulation and fertility. This was not
impossible because PCOS is a multifaceted syndrome
that affects multiple organ systems, and albeit insulin resistance is closely linked to hyperandrogenism rendering
some reproductive manifestations including infertility, the
improvement of insulin resistance by one agent alone is
not necessarily followed by reproductive health recovery.
Treatment should be individualized based on the patient’s
phenotypes, presentation, complaints and desire for pregnancy ( 33 ). Further, it is also possible that the dose and
duration of treatment with DLBS3233 might be increased
in order to significantly promote desirable fertility.  In general, clinical benefits demonstrated by DLBS3233, a standardized bioactive fraction
of C. burmanii and L. speciosa , in this study were aligned
with several studies of various cinnamon extracts that have been conducted across the globe
for PCOS treatment, which reported an improvement in HOMA-IR, insulin level, total
cholesterol, triglyceride level and body weight. The duration of cinnamon treatment in those
reported studies varied between 8 weeks to 6 months ( 35 ). In terms of reproductive
parameters, some studies also reported the improvement of the menstrual cycle and a
testosterone level reduction by the cinnamon extracts ( 35 - 37 ). Although there are limited
studies of the Lagerstoremia sp . effect for PCOS treatment, L.
speciosa has long been studied for its insulin-sensitizing capacity ( 38 ).
Nevertheless, herbal preparations are principally unique. DLBS3233 bioactive fraction
obtained from a certain proprietary fractionation technology altogether with its specific
mechanism of action and physicochemical characteristics cannot be identified with other
extracts derived from the same plants ( C. burmanii and L.
speciosa ) yet using different fractionation procedures and technology; Not to
mention the influence of different agriculture location and practice implemented for
cultivating the plants on the final extract properties. Consequently, the pharmacological
and clinical effects seen with DLBS3233 bioactive fraction in our previous ( 12 , 15 - 17 ), and
current studies cannot simply be generalized for other C. burmanii and L. speciosa combination extracts or bioactive compounds, or
even less for the individual extract of either plant. Other extracts may possess
specifically different biological activities. Bioactive compounds of Cinnamomum species are widely known to possess antimicrobial,
anti-fungal, antidiabetic, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, analgesic, anti-thrombotic,
anticancer and neuroprotective effects ( 35 ). Meanwhile, L. speciosa extracts are known with their antimicrobial, antioxidant, anticancer, antidiabetic,
hypolipidemic, antiobesity, antiinflammatory, analgesic, gastrointestinal, diuretic,
thrombolytic, cardiovascular, central nervous, hepatoprotective and nephroprotective effects
( 39 ). Therefore, this paper does not further discuss DLBS3233 in comparison with other
cinnamon or Lagerstroemia preparations, and more focuses on its clinical
benefits we can utilize in comparison with metformin for PCOS treatment, as purported by
this study.  With respect to safety evaluation, we observed that
ECG, vital signs and all laboratory examinations in both
groups did not substantially change during the study and
were all within the normal ranges, indicating that both
treatments did not adversely affect the major organ function, such as heart, liver and kidney. A slight difference in creatinine values between groups was regarded negligible
clinically. Interestingly, we observed approximately double cases of gastrointestinal adverse events of MetforminXR treatment in comparison with DLBS3233 treatment.
Besides, we found more various adverse events with
metformin-XR treatment counted a higher total number
of events during the study. This was aligned with reports
of most literature that the use of metformin was associated with a higher incidence of gastrointestinal (GI) upsets
(such as nausea, diarrhoea, vomiting and abdominal discomfort), and more rarely, lactic acidosis (particularly in
PCOS women with diabetes comorbidity) and increased
homocysteine level ( 1 , 3 , 10 , 23 , 33 ). Most adverse events
experienced were mild to moderate and did not cause participation withdrawal, but one subject in the Metformin
group due to severe nausea that was undoubtedly to be
drug-related, and one patient in the DLBS3233 group due
to moderate ovarian cyst which was certainly related to
disease progression rather than the drug-use. All adverse
events were followed up until fully resolved. Altogether,
these findings generally indicate a more favourable safety
profile and tolerability of DLBS3233 treatment than that
in the Metformin treatment. Therefore, DLBS3233 may
be a potential alternative to those who cannot tolerate the
adverse effects of metformin. Besides, long-term use of
metformin exposes patients to vitamin B12 malabsorption, thus, we need a monitoring for signs and symptoms
of vitamin B12 deficiency. A meta-analysis also found
a significantly increased prevalence of diabetes in women with PCOS ( 40 ). PCOS women with diabetes are at
increased risk to develop lactic acidosis with metformin
treatment. Those are the other circumstances in which
DLBS3233 may have bigger benefits for PCOS patients
and be a better treatment option than metformin.  We acknowledge there were limitations in our study.
First, lifestyle modification, including dietary management and exercise, which are recommended for PCOS
management ( 1 , 2 , 26 ), was not strictly controlled and
evaluated during the study. Adherence to and implementation of the lifestyle recommendation would have somehow interfered with the study results. Since the lifestyle
intervention was not part of our study design, the education was provided only in general for all subjects, without any specific or personalized diet or exercise recommended. Nevertheless, this does not diminish the value
of this study since the real-life engagement, compliance
and sustainability of lifestyle intervention remain poor, in
fact, and thus pharmacotherapy is currently recommended in addition to a lifestyle management, particularly to
optimize and maintain its clinical benefits in the long run
( 26 ). Secondly, the short-term duration of the study might
not be able to reveal the long-term efficacy and safety
profile of our investigational drug. Long-term cohort
studies may be needed to provide such data. However, at
the moment, our study findings are sufficient to warrant
the clinical application of DLBS3233, a nature-derived
insulin-sensitizing agent, as an alternative to metformin,
the most widely utilized insulin sensitizer in PCOS treatment, particularly for those who cannot well tolerate the
adverse reactions of metformin. Further, most subsequent
analyses in this study should be regarded as exploratory
instead of confirmatory findings, since the sample size
was not estimated for each secondary endpoint.    Conclusion  Daily treatment with 100 mg DLBS3233 for PCOS
women demonstrated comparable efficacy with twice
daily treatment with 750 mg metformin-XR in terms of
improving insulin resistance (HOMA-IR). However, the
non-inferiority of DLBS3233 to metformin-XR remains
inconclusive. On top of this, DLBS3233 was evidently
more tolerable than metformin-XR. The clinical findings
of the study will benefit PCOS patients since it provides a
broader range of therapeutic options for PCOS.    Supplementary PDF
